awd_titl_txt: The Physiological Genomics of Diet Switching in Mammalian Herbivores
awd_abstract_narration:
At every meal, animals that feed on plants (herbivores) such as deer, cattle, and rabbits, face the possibility of being poisoned by naturally-occurring toxic chemicals in their food.  Nevertheless, how herbivores process natural toxins remains poorly understood. For example, remarkably little is known about the specific genes that control an animal's ability to process potentially toxic compounds in plants. To address these fundamental problems, this research will focus on a dramatic dietary change: woodrats normally eat juniper and cactus, but several populations in the American southwest have switched to a diet of creosote bush. Creosote bush produces natural toxins that radically differ from juniper and cactus, and therefore the specialized woodrat populations must detoxify their diets differently than the juniper and cactus-eaters. The goal of this project is to identify DNA-level changes that are associated with woodrats' ability to feed on a toxic diet of creosote bush. This project will develop new genomic tools that will be useful to the broader scientific community. A better understanding of how animals process toxins can also impact decisions about pharmaceutical development for humans and other animals, and influence feeding options to improve production of free-ranging domestic herbivores like cattle. Results of this work will be communicated to the public through an interactive display about the ecology of woodrats at the Utah Museum of Natural History.  

Despite decades of pharmacological research on model species and humans, the mechanisms used by mammalian herbivores to metabolize plant secondary compounds and the genomic basis underlying adaptation to new diets remain poorly understood. This research will investigate the evolution of dietary adaptation and specialization in mammalian herbivores by capitalizing on a dramatic diet change event: the replacement of juniper (Juniperus spp.) and cactus (Opuntia spp.) with creosote bush (Larrea tridentata) in the diets of herbivorous woodrats. The project has three goals:  1) Identify genomic changes associated with a radical dietary shift in Neotoma lepida.  2) Test for the repeated involvement of similar genetic pathways for specialization on creosote diets in N. bryanti. 3) Characterize the transcriptomic response of parental and hybrid populations of N. lepida and N. bryanti to a creosote diet. The proposed work leverages modern evolutionary genomic approaches to address a long-standing question in physiological ecology: which mechanisms are important in the processing of toxic diets? The project will lead to a deeper understanding of the responses of organisms to changes in the environment, including fundamental information at the genomic level about how mammalian herbivores adapt to dietary toxins. The project specifically tests whether the same genomic regions are under selection in two species that independently evolved the ability to specialize on creosote diets. An interactive display about the ecology of woodrats and their importance to society will be developed in collaboration with the Utah Museum of Natural History. Genomic tools will be developed that will be useful to the broader scientific community. In addition, the PIs will mentor students (high school through graduate) and postdocs in physiological genomics research on non-model species.

por.por_cntn:
At every meal, mammalian herbivores confront the possibility of being poisoned by their food. Liver biotransformation enzymes have long been suspected to determine the diet breadth and detoxification ability of mammalian herbivores, however, despite decades of research on laboratory species, we know relatively little about the mechanisms used by mammalian herbivores to break down these poisonous plant compounds or adapt to new diets. Yet this information on how mammalian herbivores metabolize dietary toxins is critical to understand the evolution of diet shifts that entail exploiting new food sources, or that are imposed by floristic changes caused by climate change. Creosote bush (Larrea tridentata) is a prime example of one such plant that spread to new areas following a natural climate change event and necessitated rapid dietary adaptation. It advanced throughout the southwestern United States at the end of the last ice age (approximately 15,000 years ago), and due to its production of an extremely toxic resin, is currently fed upon by only a handful of herbivores. Our objective was to determine how dietary exposure to the toxins of this invasive plant shaped the detoxification strategies of two species of herbivorous rodents that independently adapted to feed upon it: the woodrats Neotoma lepida and N. bryanti.

         For this project, we generated two highly complete, chromosome-scale genome assemblies and performed extensive manual curation of biotransformation genes. We identified numerous expansions across multiple gene families in both species, with the cytochrome P450 2B and 3A subfamilies and the UDP-glucuronosyltransferase 2B (Ugt2b) subfamily exhibiting the largest numbers of duplications. We also collected over 150 woodrats from 13 sites throughout the southwestern United States with varying degrees of evolutionary exposure to creosote bush and assayed their performance on diets with increasing levels of creosote bush resin. The breadth of creosote tolerance between sites was profound; populations with no exposure to creosote bush could tolerate only small amounts of creosote resin, while one experienced population from southern California could consume a diet equivalent to 100% creosote bush. Liver gene expression results for this tolerant California population further revealed a carefully controlled response that varied in intensity based on the amount of creosote resin present in the diet.

         Leveraging comprehensive genome sequencing data, liver gene expression results, and the maximum amount of creosote resin each of the 150+ woodrats could tolerate, we were able to identify several biotransformation gene families that appeared to be under selection for creosote tolerance. Some gene families were selected in only one species, while others, like the Ugt2b subfamily, were under selection in both N. lepida and N. bryanti. Furthermore, the total number of Ugt2b genes in each genome were found to correlate with historical exposure to creosote, with creosote-tolerant individuals having more copies and higher Ugt2b expression than creosote-sensitive individuals. This indicates that gene duplication events, leading to increased gene expression, are a critical component of successful creosote bush feeding in both species. Taken together, these results provide an unprecedent look into the factors underlying the rapid adaptation of two herbivorous rodents to a novel diet and give insight into how other mammalian herbivores might adapt as they grapple with the ongoing effects of climate change.

This project provided research opportunities for numerous undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs, and was disseminated at multiple scientific conferences. It has contributed high-quality, annotated reference genomes to publicly available repositories. Aspects of this work were profiled in seven published papers, with additional manuscripts underway. Research from this project was communicated to the public via social media channels and through the creation of a new exhibit at the Natural History Museum of Utah. The work contributed to the bioeconomy through workforce training and the development of scientific infrastructure.
